message.reasoning:
Okay, so I need to figure out how to explore all the rooms with the fewest moves possible. Let's start with the initial information. The user is in the Cellar, and the only available direction is north. The goal is to visit all rooms efficiently, keeping track of the graph as we go. 

First step: From the Cellar, the only option is to go north. So I'll move north. The graph should now include the Cellar and the next room. Let's say the next room is, I don't know, maybe the Hall. So the nodes would be ["Cellar", "Hall"], and the edges would have north from Cellar to Hall. Then, when the user moves north, the edges for north would have ("Cellar", "Hall"). 

Wait, but in the example, when moving west from Living Room to Library, the west edge was [("Living Room", "Library")]. So the direction from the starting room to the new room is the direction taken. So if I go north from Cellar to Hall, then the north edge in the graph would have ("Cellar", "Hall").
